SP.P: No.
In Spanish?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
In High-Dutch?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
In French?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
Latin?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
Greek?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
Hebrew?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
In Syriack?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
In Turkish?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No.
Arabick?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No, no, no, no. English.
Ho! in English — very well. — Then come on t'other side, for this Ear is kept only for Stran∣gers, and the other for our Mother Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Here's a great deal of Ceremony with these People.Aside.
Well, what wou'd you ask now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: I told you before, Sir, but I perceive you did not mind me, why I wou'd consult you upon a little Difficulty.
A Difficulty in Philosophy without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Excuse me, I—
Perhaps you wou'd know if the Substance and Accident, are Terms synonimous or equivocal, in regard of their being.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Not at all, I wou'd—
If Logick be an Art, or Science.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No nor that, I —
Whether it has three Operations of the Mind, or the third only.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No, I —
If there is ten Categories, or if there be but one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Neither, I —
If the Conclusion be of the Essence, or of the Syllogism.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No, no, no, no.
If the good be reciprocal with the end.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Zouns, no —Stamps.
If the end can move us by a real Being, or by an intentional Being.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No, no; by the Devil and all his Imps, no.
Why then explain your Mind, for I can't guess it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: So I will explain my self, but you won't hear me. I tell you I have a mind to marry, I have her Father's Consent and hers too, but I'm afraid —

Words be given to Man to explain his Mind, the Mind is the Picture of Things, as our Words are the Pictures of our Meaning; but these Pictures differ from all other Pictures, insomuch as other Pictures are distinguish'd by their Originals; and the Word keeps in it self the original Being, that it is nothing else but the Mind explain'd by some exterior Sign or Motion; whence it comes that those who think well talk the better; ex∣plain then your Mind by your Word, which is the most intelligible of all the Signs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: A Pox take you and all your Signs and Fi∣gures; get in and be damn'd, get in.Pushes him in.
Ha, ha, ha.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Oh! Mr. Octavio, are you come, Pox take your learned Man here, he won't hear one Word a Man has to say to him; I never was so plagu'd in all my Life, phugh,—Walks about in a Heat.

I just heard his Character, Sir Toby, and came to your Relief; faith I had but small Acquaintance with him, as I told you before, only coming over in the same Ship with him; but I have heard of another a very sober discreet Person, they say, if you please you may con∣sult him, he lodges at the Sign of the Globe in the
next Street; I have a little Business at present, or I'd wait on you, Sir Toby, I hope you'll excuse me.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Sir, your Servant.—A Pox on this Fellow, I shan't be my self again this Hour, yet I'm resolved to hear what t'other says; for if there is any Possibility of esca∣ping Cuckoldom, I wou'd marry this Girl.Exit
Excellently well performed, Bellmie; why you cant learnedly, and wou'd make an admirable Fortune∣teller, ha! thou'rt a handsome Fellow, and wou'd have all the Ladies Customs.
Pox take this old Dog, he has put me quite out of Breath, I had much ado to forbear laughing.
Nor I, but come let's consider who shall perso∣nate the other learned Man; what think you of doing it your self?
With all my Heart.
You must alter your Dress then, and represent a Man whose Temper and Principles are just opposite to all you did just now; seem to doubt every thing, and be positive in nothing, d'ye hear?
I'll warrant you, let me alone for cross Purposes.
Come, you must about it immediately; in the mean time I'll go and tell Mr. Selfwill Sir Toby wou'd speak with him at the Globe, I'll be sure to get him abroad, then do as we agreed on.Exeunt.
I can't imagine where Sir Toby is gone, I won∣der he shou'd go out of the way, when he knew I was gone for the Parson.
It is not very civil truly.
I hope he'll never come again.Aside.

Ladies, your humble Servant. Mr. Selfwill, Sir Toby humbly begs your Pardon, he met with some Friends that detain him against his Will, at the Globe, where he desires you'd meet him; and he also begs the Favour of this Lady to give me leave to wait on her to the Church, where he'll meet her instantly; for what reason I know not, but he says he's resolved not to be married out of a Church, which I believe was the cause of his going away.
Nay, if that be all, with all my heart.
'Tis to Bellmie, Madam, I conduct you.
D'ye hear, Daughter, let Mr. Octavio wait on you, as Sit Toby des: Niece, you'll bear her Com∣pany, and see her given away.
But not to the Man you expect, Uncle.
Mr. Octavio your Servant.Exit.
Sir, yours. Now, Madam, if Fortune favours us, Bellmie will be happy. Turning to Belliza. Ma∣dam, have you no Charity, how long must I serve e'er you reward my Service?
Serve me, Sir! this is the first Moment I knew I had such a Servant; I shall observe with what Di∣ligence you officiate for the future.

For the future! ods life, Madam, what do you mean? If you knew my Constitution half so well as I do, you'd reward me presently; for I have serv'd already, in my Opinion, a Patriarch's Apprentice∣ship.
Nay, if your Account runs so swiftly, I'm afraid you'll forget you e'er serv'd at all.
No, Madam, bind me but once fast in Marriage-Bonds, and I shall become as errant a Husband as you'd wish.
The Gentleman promises fair, Cousin; pray try him.
First let me see you disposed of, what that may put into my Head I know not, but I'll promise nothing.
But perform, I hope, as much as those that do; I'll still hope the best: Come, Ladies, my Friend will be impatient.Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the Globe.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bellmie on one side, and Sir Toby on the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Doctor, your Servant.
Sir, your very humble Servant; pray what is your Business?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Ay, this Man is something like, he'll give one leave to speak. Aside. I am come, Doctor. —

Hold, Sir, change, if you please, your way of talking; our Philosophy teaches never to be posi∣tive in any thing, always suspend your Judgment. — By that Rule you must not say you are come, but you believe you are come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Believe I am come!
Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: I must believe it because it is so.
That is not the Consequence, you may be∣lieve it to be so, tho' the thing is not true.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: How! what, is it not true that I am come?
That's uncertain, and we are to doubt of any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What! am not I here, and don't you talk to me?
I believe you are there, and I think I talk to you, but am not certain of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What the Devil do ye banter me? I am here, and I see you there plain enough, yet there's no Belief in it. Pray let all these Whims alone, and let us talk of our Business, I come to tell you I have a mind to marry.
I don't know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Why but I tell you.
That may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: And the Lady that I design for my Wife is young and handsom.
That's not impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Shall I do well, or ill to marry her.
One or the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Ha! here's another Rogue now. Asde. I ask you if I shall do well to marry that Lady.
According as it proves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Shall I do ill?
Peradventure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, answer me as you shou'd do.
'Tis my Design.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: I have a great Inclination for the Maid.
Not unlikely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: I have her Father's Consent.
It may be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: But in marrying her I'm afraid of being a Cuckold.
It may be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: May it so, Sir?
There's no Impossibility.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Did ever any body hear such a cautious Dog. Aside. But what wou'd you do, if you were in my place?
I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What wou'd you counsel me to do?
What you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: You'll make me mad.Looking angrily.
I wash my Hands of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: The Devil take him.Aside.
Look'e, Sir, what will happen, will happen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Pox on this Dog, I'll make you change your Note, I'll warrant you. Beats him. There's for your Nonsense, now I'm satisfied.
What Insolence is this, to strike a Philoso∣pher, a Man of Learning as I am?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Pray, good Doctor, change your way of talking, you must not be positive, in any thing, you must not say I beat you, the most you can say is, that you believe I beat you.
I'll instantly make my Complaint to a Justice, I'll have Satisfaction for the Blows I received.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: I wash my Hands on't.
I have the Marks upon my Shoulders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: That may be.
'Tis you have given me 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: That's not impossible.
I shall have a Warrant for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: I know nothing of the matter.
And you shall make me Satisfaction, or go to Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What will happen, will happen. Ha, ha, ha.
Ay, let me alone with you.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P:
The Devil go with you and all such con∣founded Dogs, one can't get a word positive from 'em; a little canting Nonsense, what a Pox do they pretend to Learning for? I knew as much before I came as I do now, what shall I do in this Incertitude? If I marry I shall certainly be a Cuckold, and my Children Bastards.
—There must be something in these Fellows Shufflings, for burn 'em they are wise Men when one has said all; and therefore they certainly know I shall be a Cuckold if I marry, but are afraid to tell me so; therefore I will not marry I am resolved, and so I'll go and tell Mr. Self∣will. Ha! what is he come to ask Advice to?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Mr. Selfwill your humble Servant, what do you do here?
Why did you not send for me, Sir Toby?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Not I, Sir.
What! did you not send Octavio for me, and order'd him to wait on my Daughter to Church, where you'd meet her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Upon my Faith, not I. I was just a coming to tell you I have alter'd my Design of Marriage, my Years do not suit with Matrimony; and therefore I desire you to dispose of your Daughter to whom you please; I beg your Pardon, but won't marry I'm resolved.
How! how's this, Sir Toby! Do you make a Fool of my Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Not I, Mr. Selfwill, — nor do I design your Daughter shall make a Cuckold of me. — Aside.
What do you mean by saying you won't marry?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Just as I say, I mean, — I will not marry I tell you.
Did you not send for me, say you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: No, Sir.
Nor for my Daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Neither.

O Lord! I'm ruin'd, undone. Stamps. Who is this Octavio? Sir Toby, you are a Knave, I doubt in my Conseience. I believe you have pretended Love to my Daughter all this while, only to put a Trick upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby,
SP.P: Have a care what you say, Mr. Selfwill; egad I won't take an Affront.Holds up his Cane.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bellmie, Octavio, Lucinda and Belliza.

SP.P: Hold, Gentlemen, I hope you are not in earnest; Sir Toby, I have brought your Bride. Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: She shall be Your Bride if you will, Sir.
Here's a Gentleman has a better Title to her.
Your Blessing, Sir.To Selfwill kneeling.
What the Devil! you are not married, are you?
'Tis even so, Mr. Selfwill.

Why then take her, but not a Groat of mine along with her, I'll promise you that; there's five hun∣dred a Year her Grandmother left her, which I can't hinder her of, I wish I cou'd, you shou'd starve together.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Tal, dera, dal, dal, dal; I'm glad I'm shut of her, for if she cou'd steal a Husband, she'd have stole the Devil and all of Gallants. Aside. But I thought, Mr. Octavio, you was my Friend.
So I am, Sir Toby; did I not tell you from the first, Marriage wou'd not agree with your Years? ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, Sir, and I thank you for your Care.
Mr. Selfwill, Uncle I mean, give me your Hand, and let's be Friends.

Uncle! why what, my Daughter did not set your Chops a watering too, did she Niece, ha? I wish you much Joy, if there can come any such thing from the Sex, for I'm in doubt if there can or no; she has a good Fortune, as long as that lasts you may live well enough, and when 'tis spent there's Hedges and Barns in the Country; hang, drown, or starve, I care not.Exit.
Ha, ha, ha.

SP.L: You shall both Father, Friend, and Husband find,
I ne'er can want of ought while you are kind.

SP.P: Sir, I have brought the Musick.
That's well, we'll have a Dance however; but first let me beg one Favour of you, Sir Toby.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: What's that, Sir?
Only to forgive this Fellow, and make one in our Diversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: Forgive him! why I don't know him.

Not my Person perhaps, Sir Toby, but my Parts you do. I am he that sold you Oranges, Master, like∣wise the Doctor that restor'd this Lady to her Speech; and this Gentleman, Pointing to Bellmie. by my Advice, personated the two famous Astrologers of whom you enquired your Fortune, whether or no you should be a Cuckold, Master; do you know us now, Sir?
Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: A thorough pac'd Rogue, — Why what an Ass have I been made on. Aside. Hark'e, Sirrah, don't you expect to be hang'd, ye Dog?
I am married, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby.
SP.P: You are married, why then may the Curse of Cuckoldom light on thee, or what's worse, the Fear of it. Good by to you all.Exit.
Ha, ha, ha, ha.All laugh.
Well, Martin, your Wife and you shall live with me for the future, but you shall beat her no more.
Nay, I'm pretty even with him, Sir, for I put him off for a Doctor, and got him well drub'd into the Bargain.
A very cunning Stratagem, but come let the Di∣version begin.

LG.L: SƲE to Caelia for the Favour,
As if he were sole Receiver,
Were not Love condemn'd to Blindness
Tho' to him she feign the Kindness,
She's to her self most kind.
Let us banish then the Fashion,

SP.P: Come, my Belliza, you shall find tho' I have hi∣therto talk'd wildly, that I love in earnest.

Q.L: My Study shall be still for your Content,
Give me but Love, you never shall repent.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: WHat, if to end this Fortune-telling Play,
I tell you all your Fortunes here to Day;
And, faith, to judge by here and there a Face,
Fortune has Fav'rites scatter'd in this place:
The Beans, whose Garb of late such Lustre darts,
To draw fair Ladies Eyes, and break poor Tradesmens Hearts,
Their Fortune is what still attends the Great,
Still borrowing, still dunn'd, and still in Debt.
Pit-masks this Season are grown mighty bare,
They scarce got Pattings to ply round May-Fair.
But when the Term, and Winter comes agen,
Bawds, Brims, and Lawyers flourish bravely then.
Vintners and Taylors thro' such Knavish Lives,
With honest Citts, and virtuous City Wives;
I fear (tho' wishing it might be uncivil)
Like Pawn-Brokers, they'll all go to the Devil:
The City Prentices, those upstart Beaus,
In short spruce Puffs, and Vigo Colour Clothes,
Who with a Brace of Trulls stole here to Day,
And muster'd up a Crown to see this Play;
Lewdness and Gaming will run them aground,
And Masters Cash fall short a hundred Pound.
Our upper Friends, whose Height Respect denotes,
Since Liv'ries too are not unlike tac'd Coats,
By coming will such Criticks grow at last,
Nothing but Standard-Wit will please their Taste,
Till learning here how well the Town's harangu'd,
They'll make ingenious Speeches when they're hang'd.
Our Fidlers will, be scraping as before,
Spend ev'ry Groat they get upon a Whore,
Lead merry Lives, damn'd shabby, and damn'd poor:
But where at last they'll go, is hard, to tell,
For really they're too impudent for Hell.
The Ladies, by their melting Looks, I see,
Will die for Love, perhaps for Love of me;
My Pity flows apace to save their Life,
I cou'd be kind, but must not wrong my Wife.
But lastly, for the Fortune of this Play,
Humour's a Hazard, get thus much I'll say,
The Author purely for your Mirth design'd it,
And whether good or bad, 'tis— As you find it.
